Award.AbstractNarration:
The Integrating Engineering and Literacy (IEL) project is developing and testing curriculum materials and a professional development model designed to explore the potential for introducing engineering concepts in grades 3 - 5 through design challenges based on stories in popular children's literature. The project research and development team at Tufts University is working with pre-service teachers to design and test the curriculum modules for students and the teacher professional development model. Then the program is tested and refined in work with 100 in-service teachers and their students in a diverse set of Massachusetts schools. The research team hypothesizes that professional development for elementary teachers using an interdisciplinary method for combining literature with engineering design challenges will increase the implementation of engineering in 3-5 classrooms and have positive impacts on students.

The driving questions behind this proposed research are: (1) How do teachers' engineering (and STEM) content knowledge, pedagogical content knowledge, and perceptions or attitudes toward engineering influence their classroom teaching of engineering through literacy? (2) Do teachers create their own personal conceptions of the engineering design process, and what do these conceptions look like? (3) What engineering/reading thinking skills are students developing by participating in engineering activities integrated into their reading and writing work? The curriculum materials and teacher professional development model are being produced by a design research strategy that uses cycles of develop/test/refine work. The effects of the program are being evaluated by a variety of measures of student and teacher learning and practice.

The project will contribute materials and research findings to the ultimate goal of understanding how to provide elementary school students with meaningful opportunities to learn engineering and develop valuable problem solving and thinking skills.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

Integrating Engineering and Literacy, commonly known as Novel Engineering, is a research and development project that created and studied an integrated approach to supporting grades 3-5 classroom teachers’ integration of engineering with required English language arts texts. The project, developed at Tufts Center for Engineering Education and Outreach, has shown a new model for engineering integration where the disciplines are truly dependent on each other and students successfully navigate between the two in a rich context. The Novel Engineering approach positions texts (novels, short stories, picture books) as the source for engineering design challenges that leverages the characters, setting, and thematic story elements. Characters become the clients and the setting provides design constraints. Materials used for design tasks in Novel Engineering are flexible, usually using recycled and craft materials, so that materials are available to all schools in an effort make Novel Engineering dissemination equitable. The project created a scalable professional development model that prepares classroom teachers to use the approach with their own curriculum and supports them in using progressive pedagogical techniques that address classroom goals, allowing Novel Engineering to be used in a wide variety of districts and settings. Research for the project adds to the understanding of how students navigate the two disciplines of engineering and literacy in this integrated context.

Broader Impacts

Novel Engineering’s interdisciplinary approach provides an easy access point for teachers of varied experience with engineering & engineering design, allowing them to build on their experience and pedagogical strategies in literacy to include engineering and engineering design in their classrooms. In Novel Engineering literacy is seen as deep reading, comprehension, engagement, and authentic writing. Through Novel Engineering professional development (PD), teachers gain an understanding of what engineering with open-ended problems looks like in elementary school and how they can authentically integrate the two disciplines in classroom tasks, meeting goals for each discipline.

Research associated with Novel Engineering has advanced knowledge and contributed to the area of engineering education both in understanding the nature of students’ engineering abilities and design principles for teacher PD. Novel Engineering advances understandings of  how students engage in engineering classroom activities and how their understanding influences what abilities and practices we see students leverage for learning. In Novel Engineering, students are able to navigate between classroom restrictions, constraints presented by the text, and the requirements of the real world. The current research literature often talks about students’ limitations or inabilities. Novel Engineering findings add to the conversations about young students sophisticated abilities and knowledge and while pushing for more work on unpacking the significance of context for students.

Novel Engineering research also looked at teachers engaged in professional development and reflection on students’ work in Novel Engineering. A component of the Novel Engineering professional development is to practice responsive teaching, which requires teachers to elicit, notice, and respond to student thinking rather than exclusively following prescribed curriculum. The approach seems particularly relevant for engineering design, which involves multiple pathways and varied solutions. The basis for responsive teaching is that teachers are integral to what is happening in their classrooms and students are seen as capable with productive ideas.

Conjectures for designing PD identified during this project revolve around teachers readily recognizing engineering design tasks as opportunities for students to generate and pursue ideas. These conjectures include using pre-design and mid-design share-outs to create opportunities for teachers to elicit student thinking. When designing professional development, it should be recognized that teachers’ attention to the engineering design process can be both a tool and a barrier for interpreting students’ work. Research found that teachers’ care for students’ social interactions could be a productive entry for making disciplinary interpretations of students’ thinking and that teachers recognize the need to balance multiple objectives may help teachers respond to students’ work. Additionally, models and resources for preparing teachers to teach engineering such as using video of students engaged in engineering to develop teacher’s ability to notice engineering were developed as part of this grant.   

Several tools and technologies were developed as part of this grant. These include paperbots, Smartposts, and a documentation station. Each of these technologies was developed in response to a need seen during research. Paperbots offered students an additional tool for product development. Smartposts was developed as a platform for Novel Engineering websites. A documentation station was developed as a way for students to reflect on their work and for teachers to understand their students’ design and design process.

The Novel Engineering dissemination package includes a one-day professional development workshop with the option to do a year-long, graduate-level online course in an effort to make sustained changes in teaching. Novel Engineering dissemination has a national focus with partners in Indiana, Tennessee, Missouri, New York, and North Carolina who have been trained as Novel Engineering facilitators who can offer Novel Engineering PD.
